Fig. 2 A generalized schematic illustration showing the use of MXenes in HER. Fig. 3 (a) Top view of the atomic structure of bare MXene with different adsorption sites; (b) HER volcano plot with the theoretical overpotential values for the investigated MXenes where red and blue circles represent carbides and nitrides based MXenes with the two MXenes that are studied in the experiment (Ti2C and Mo2C) indicated by stars; (c) zoomed-in portion volcano plot; (d, e) SEM images of Mo2CT x and Ti2CT x ; (f) anodic-going iR-corrected LSVs of Mo2CT x and Ti2CT x , along with that of bare glassy carbon; (g) temporal evolution of the potential required to maintain a constant current density of 10 mA cm−2; (h) SEM image of d-Mo2CT x on an alumina filter; (i) anodic-going iR-corrected LSVs of d-Mo2CT x in comparison with Mo2CT x [30] (Copyright © 2016, American Chemical Society). Fig. 4 (a, b) Negative of the overpotential of carbide and nitride MXenes (left and right panels, respectively) plotted against the free energy of hydrogen adsorption (ΔG H) [47] (Copyright © 2017, American Chemical Society); (c) Bader charge (ΔQ) of V3CNO2−2 x (OH)2 x at different OH coverages [49] (Copyright © 2018 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim). Fig. 5 The effects of surface terminations on HER: (a) the volcano curve of exchange current (i 0) against the function of the average Gibbs free energy of hydrogen adsorption (ΔG H*) [50] (Copyright © 2017, American Chemical Society); (b) LSVs and (c) Tafel plots of various Ti3C2T x in 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte [51] (Copyright © 2018, American Chemical Society); (d) schematic illustration of the synthesis of Ti3C2O x [27] (Copyright © 2019 Wiley‐VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim); (e) polarization curves and (f) Nyquist plots of the annealed-Ti2CT x nanosheets and alkalized-Ti2CT x nanosheets [60] (Copyright © 2018 Elsevier Ltd.). Fig. 6 Different methods to prepare fluorine-free MXene. (a) The reaction between Ti3AlC2 and NaOH water solution under different conditions [53] (Copyright © 2018 Wiley‐VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim); (b) schematic of Ti3C2T x MXene preparation by Lewis acidic etching route [54] (Copyright © 2020, Springer Nature); and (c) n-BuLi-modified and alkali-modified MXene synthesis respectively [59] (Copyright © 2019, American Chemical Society). Graphical abstract This review focuses on the recent progresses, mechanisms of action and regulation directions on MXenes-based electrocatalysts in HER including pristine MXenes and MXenes-based composites. The growing energy concern all over the world has recognized hydrogen energy as the most promising renewable energy sources. Recently, electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) by water splitting has been extensively studied with a focus on developing efficient electrocatalysts that can afford HER at overpotential with minimum power consumption. The two-dimensional transition metal carbides and nitride, also known as MXenes, are becoming the rising star in developing efficient electrocatalysts for HER, owing to their integrated chemical and electronic properties, e.g., metallic conductivity, variety of redox-active transition metals, high hydrophilicity, and tunable surface functionalities. In this review, the recent progress about the fundamental understanding and materials engineering of MXenes-based electrocatalysts is summarized in concern with two aspects: i) the regulation of the intrinsic properties of MXenes, which include the composition, surface functionality, and defects; and ii) MXenes-based composites for HER process. In the end, we summarize the present challenges concerning the efficiency of MXenes-based HER electrocatalysts and propose the directions of future research efforts. Keywords MXenes Hydrogen evolution reaction Electrochemical water splitting 1 Introduction The rising energy shortages and aggravated environment pollution, has drawn substantial attention to the development of clean energy technologies. Here, hydrogen as energy has attracted much attention due to its rich resources and high calorific value among new energies-technologies [1–3]. Among the easiest yet, the preparative approach of producing hydrogen is via water electrolysis, which is recognized as a simple and mature technology that can produce a high purity H2 for energy purposes. Although simple, the water electrolysis has an overpotential, determining that the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) potential is lower than the theoretical value of 0 V and causes energy loss [4–6]. Here, a suitable catalyst can significantly lower the overpotential value resulting in an efficient HER. To achieve an efficient HER process, the understanding of its mechanism is crucial in designing a superior electrocatalyst. Fig. 1 shows the generalized HER mechanism, where intermediate product, H*, can be seen formed from the adsorbed hydrogen (Volmer reaction), followed by a hydrogen desorption process (Tafel reaction or Heyrovsky reaction) to release produced H2 gas [7,8]. The Gibbs free energy of hydrogen adsorption (denoted as ΔG H*), which represents the binding strength of H* on the electrocatalyst surface, is the most frequent descriptors for the difficulty of initiating a reaction over a catalyst. The expected value of ΔG H* is close to zero, meaning the equilibrium between the adsorption and desorption processes, thus making it suitable for hydrogen evolution. Currently, the Pt/C catalyst is one of the noble metal-based catalysts, primarily used as commercial catalysts for HER. The catalyst is composed of Pt loaded on carbon black, with Pt content in the range from 5% to 20%. The partially filled d orbital of Pt can easily interact with the H 1s orbital and serves as an active H adsorption site. Although efficient, the Pt/C catalyst has limitations of high cost, poisoning effect, and pH-dependency. Thus, it has become a necessity to develop an alternative efficient HER catalysts. Since HER is based on adsorption/desorption of hydrogen, the interaction between active sites and hydrogen can significantly affect the catalytic process. The d-band of noble metals can moderately interact with H* which is conducive to the adsorption and desorption process. Theoretically, the transition metals, such as iron (Fe), cobalt (Co), nickel (Ni), molybdenum (Mo), and tungsten (W), can act as HER electrocatalysts based on similarities of their band structure to Pt. However, their catalytic activity could hardly be compared to Pt due to their strong binding force with H, making desorption process a rate-limiting step in the HER. The d-band center theory proposed by Norskov [9,10] provides a viewpoint for regulating the bonding force between transition metals and hydrogen atoms over the catalytic surface. Thus, the catalytic activity of transition metals could be improved by adjusting the electronic structure. For example, the formation of alloys could change the d-band state of the transition metals, thereby modulating the binding forces. Here, when a small-radius based atoms are introduced into the lattice-structures, the d-band contracts allowing the center of d-band to move up toward the Fermi energy level. This weakens the interaction between the transition metal and H, promoting faster desorption of hydrogen and improving the catalytic activity. The exploration of the d-band center theory has realized transition metal compounds, such as transition metal borides [11], carbides [12], nitrides [13,14], phosphates [8], sulfides [15–17], selenides [18], to be suitable candidates for HER. The introduction of non-metal elements to regulate the d-band structure of the transition metals and bring them closer to the d-band structure of the noble metals is also proven efficient in improving the catalytic activity. However, only a few electrocatalysts have been reported to achieve comparable performance to that of Pt/C. The development of efficient electrocatalysts is still necessary and urgent. In recent years, the two-dimensional (2D) materials have become the center of attention for electrochemical energy storage and energy conversion based on their wide variety and large specific surface area. A growing interest has been observed in their application for electrocatalytic HER. As the HER involves the transfer of protons and electrons to the active site, the mass transfer and the electron transfer are equally crucial for the catalysts under investigation. Graphene has the advantages of high specific surface area, good conductivity, and electrochemical stability. However, it has fewer active sites and poor electrocatalytic activity [19]. The 1T-MoS2 features propitious conductivity and sulfur edges, which can serve as active sites for HER. However, the 1T phase is unstable and tends to change to a stable 2H phase with poor electron transportation [20]. The layered double hydroxides (LDHs) also suffer from poor conductivity, instability, and low activity [21]. Most recently, a new type of 2D materials, transition metal carbides, nitrides, and carbonitrides (MXenes) have been gaining increasing interest in HER process. MXenes were first reported in 2011. The Ti3C2T x was among the first configuration, which was obtained from the Ti3AlC2 by etching the Al layer using HF [22]. The Ti3C2T x driven from one of the ternary carbides and nitrides family (MAX), the formula of which is M n +1AX n where “M,” “A,” “X” stands for early transition metals, main group elements, and carbon or nitrogen, respectively. In the MAX phase, the “M” atomic layer and the “A” atomic layer are arranged alternately in a periodic manner forming a hexagonal close-packed structure with the “X” atom locating in the octahedral interstice [23,24]. Since the M-A bond is weaker than the M-X bond, the “A” atomic layer is selectively etched from the MAX phase using HF [25,26]. The etched products are then known as MXenes with formula M n +1X n T x , where “T” stands for the terminal groups present on the surface of MXenes, such as -F, -OH, and -O. At present only a few configurations including Ti3C2T x [27], Ti2CT x [28], Ti2NT [29], Mo2CT x [30], Nb4C3T x [31] have been successfully prepared. The layered structure, highly adjustable transition metals configuration and surface groups, large specific surface area, hydrophilicity, and metal-like conductivity allow MXenes to display a variety of electrical, optical, and magnetic properties. This has enabled MXenes to demonstrate its suitability in various energy storage and conversion technologies, including capacitor [32–35], batteries [36–38], hydrogen storage [39], and catalysis [40,41]. MXenes are potential candidates for HER. The out-layer transition metal imparts electrocatalytic potential. At the same time, the C or N atoms in the middle-layer and the surface terminations regulates the electronic structure of MXenes [26,42,43]. The active sites of MXenes are located on the whole basal surface, which is advantageous compared to transition metal sulfides whose active sites only exist on the edge [44]. This, combined with high conductivity and excellent hydrophilicity, recognizes MXenes as a suitable candidate as electrocatalyst for HER. In this review, a generalized overview is provided concerning the methodologies of regulating the electrocatalytic activity of MXenes-based electrocatalysts about both experimental and theoretical approaches. As shown in Fig. 2 , the review systematically discusses the regulatory mechanism in consideration of pristine MXenes, with elementary compositions of “M” or “X,” surface terminations, point defects, and MXenes-based nanocomposites, including MXenes-supported nanohybrids and MXenes-based heterostructures. Finally, a perspective is provided on the recent development of MXenes-based electrocatalysts for HER to further the exploration of the most suitable yet efficient electrocatalyst for commercial H2 production. 2 Pristine MXenes as HER catalyst 2.1 Effects of the compositions The transitional metal species of MXenes, i.e., “M” can directly affect the electronic characteristics of MXene and thus the HER activity. As many studies have suggested, the electrocatalytic activity of Mo-based MXenes are relatively better than that of Ti-based MXenes. Vojvodic et al. compared the HER performance of Mo2CT x and Ti2CT x in view of theoretical calculation as shown in Fig. 3 . The Mo2CT x showed a higher activity compared to Ti2CT x [30]. The density functional theory (DFT) calculation presented in Fig. 3(a, b and c) confirmed that the ΔG H* of Mo2CT x was closer to 0 compared to Ti2CT x , justifying its superior H binding capability [45]. The SEM images of Mo2CT x and Ti2CT x are shown in Fig. 3(d and e). The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) (Fig. 3f and g) under acidic conditions (0.5 M H2SO4) were consistent with the theoretical calculation. When the current reached 10 mA·cm−2, the overpotential (denoted as η 10) of Ti2CT x was 609 mV, while the Mo2CT x exhibited a lower value of 283 mV. Further experiments proved that exfoliating Mo2CT x into a single layer or several layers could influence the HER performance (Fig. 3h and i). As the basal plane of MXene is active, exfoliation could directly benefit in increasing specific surface area (SSA). In accordance to the DFT calculation produced by Mohsen Asle Zaeem et al., MXenes with “X” as C have more significant lattice constants and stability compared to MXenes with “X” as N, while MXenes with “X” as N had stronger surface activity [46]. Although significant, it does not imply that nitrides have better catalytic activity for HER. For example, Kristian et al. calculated the ΔGH* for M4X3A2, M3X2A2 and M2XA2 to determine their theoretical electrocatalytic performance [47]. The “A” reflects “O” as because the existing studies have proven that the O groups are beneficial to the structural stability of MXenes. However, the calculation shown in Fig. 4 (a and b) indicate that the replacement of “C” or “N” had no significant regularity on the catalytic activity of material. Regarding Ti-based MXenes, the ΔG H* of Ti4C3O2, Ti3C2O2, and Ti2CO2 were 0.16, 0.15, and 0.4 eV, respectively. While the ΔG H* of Ti4N3O2, Ti3N2O2 and Ti2NO2 was 0.53, 0.67 and 0.3 eV, respectively. Therefore, the performance of MXenes in HER cannot merely be judged based on configuration or the type of “X” atoms. This was also true for other transition metal-based MXenes, such as Mo-based or V-based MXenes. In this context, not only the properties of “M” and “X” must be considered, but also the interaction between the two and the influence of monolayer configuration should be considered in HER performance. Although it is believed the active sites of MXenes are located on the surface, the participation of “X” (“C” or “N” atoms) in the electrocatalysis has also been reported. Zhao et al. proved it through the first-principle calculation. When cutting MXenes nanosheets into nanoribbon and exposing the edges, C (N) atoms tended to bond with H* in acidic media [48]. The binding force with H* could be regulated by adjusting the composition of MXenes and the width of nanoribbons. Li et al. investigated the catalytic activity of M3CN MXenes with double “X” based on DFT calculations [49]. The difference in double “X” MXenes and single “X” MXenes is that the structure on both sides of the former is asymmetrical, which brought more difficulties to the surface electronic structure regulation of bare M3CN MXenes. As shown in Fig. 4(c), the HER activity is related to the charge state of O atoms on the surface, which in turn is affected by the coverage of OH. However, the two-sided asymmetric electronic structure of M3CN MXenes formed from C and N layer requires more complex protocols to be considered for regulation, which at present is difficult to achieve via experiment. Thus, the influence of “M” and “X” on HER activity is still mostly theoretical based on few experimental evidences to support the predicted data. As the synthesis condition can directly influence the properties of the material, and with no universal synthesis condition yet present to different synthesis kinds of MXenes, comparison of HER performance based on electronic structures and configuration is complicated. 2.2 Effects of surface terminations The hydrofluoric acid or a mixture of HCl and LiF is commonly used for etching MXenes from the MAX phase, resulting in surface -O, -OH, and -F terminations. The regulation of these surface terminations has been widely studied, and the type and density of the surface terminations have proven to influence the electrocatalytic activity. Du et al. investigated the HER catalytic activity of O-terminated MXenes using theoretical calculation [50]. The O-terminations were inclined to bond with H and thus considered as an active site for HER. To understand the influence of O terminations, ΔG H* of bare MXenes (M n C n −1) and O-terminated MXenes (M n C n −1O2) were calculated and compared, as shown in Fig. 5 (a). It is evident that the interactions between bare MXenes and H* are strong, whereas this interaction weakens with the introduction of oxygen terminations leading to ΔG H* to approach zero. This confirmed the O terminations could affect successful regulated surface electronic properties and improved the HER performance. In another approach, Seh et al. synthesized three kinds of Ti3C2T x obtained using different etchants to explore the role of F groups in the HER activity [51]. The study reported the use of LiF + HCl, 10% HF, and 50% HF to etch MAX phase and obtain different fluorine contents proportional to the concentrations of HF. Interestingly, it was observed that MXenes, with the lowest F content, exhibited the highest HER activity. The η 10 of MXenes etched by LiF + HCl, 10% HF, and 50% HF were obtained 536, 767, and 891 mV, respectively (Fig. 5b). The Tafel slopes (128~190 mV·dec−1) shown in Fig. 5(c) exceeded the theoretical Tafel slope of the Volmer reaction (118 mV·dec−1), indicating that the adsorption process of H* is the rate-determining step. The obtained data suggested that the F terminations were immune to exhibit any activity for HER process. The DFT was later used to calculate the changes in HER activity after adding different content of F termination over bare Ti3C2 and Ti2C MXenes. The produced results indicated that the ΔG H* increases as the amount of F termination increases. Furthermore, the effects of F terminations on specific MXenes were particularly interesting. For example, the increased F terminations in the case of Mo-based MXenes such as Mo2CT x , Mo2TiC2T x , and Mo2Ti2C3T x , results in H* to become highly unstable resulting in the formation of HF with instead of releasing H2, and driving HER towards less-effectiveness. Thus, it is crucial to control the content of F groups at a low level during synthesizing Mo-based MXenes. Based on these theories, Su et al. obtained O-terminated MXenes (Ti3C2O x ) by alkalization and annealing process. The electrochemical measurement indicated its superior HER performance, with a η 10 value of 190 mV [27]. To further ensure the function of MXene's surface group, it is particularly important to improve the antioxidant capability of MXenes in a humid environment. Here, Zhu et al. deposited TiOF2 nanoparticles over the surface of Ti3C2T x (Fig. 5d), which then stabilized the oxygen-containing termination, maintaining the inherent electronic properties and surface group activity [52]. To date, many methods have been reported to regulate the surface groups on MXenes. Zhang et al. obtained fluorine-free MXenes by etching the MAX phase with 27.5 M NaOH using hydrothermal reaction at 270 °C, as shown in Fig. 6 (a) [53]. Huang et al. used water-free etching of the MAX phase by using Lewis acid (Fig. 6b), to obtain fluorine-free MXenes [54]. However, this route resulted in replacement F with Cl terminations, whose effect on HER is unknown. Since F groups are unstable under concentrated alkali conditions, the conversion of such groups to O terminations by alkalization and annealing process is also a suitable option [55–57]. However, the concentrated alkali could damage the morphology of MXenes [58]. Fan et al. proposed that the use of n-butyl lithium in place of concentrated alkali could achieve better F-removal effects without damaging the morphology (Fig. 6c) [59]. In summary, the O terminations over MXenes are beneficial to HER catalysis, and thus the synthetic route of O-terminated MXenes needs further exploration. Although O-terminations of MXenes is recognized as the active sites for electrochemical hydrogen evolution, some reports are in support of the contribution of F terminations in HER catalysis. Xie et al. prepared Ti2CT x , alkalized-Ti2CT x nanosheets with moderate surface fluorine termination groups, and annealed-Ti2CT x nanosheets without oxygen-terminations and tested their electrocatalytic properties [60]. Fig. 5(e) confirms the LSV curve of annealed-Ti2CT x was close to pristine MXene, proving the catalytic contribution of oxygen-containing terminations. The overpotential value was relatively large for alkalized-Ti2CT x nanosheets, which is the evidence that F terminations can play a part in the HER process. The Nyquist plots in Fig. 5(f) further revealed that the annealed-Ti2CT x had relatively superior conductivity compared to alkalized-Ti2CT x counterpart, indicating the contribution of F-termination in boosting the electron transportation. 2.3 Effects of the point defects Point defects of MXenes can allow more flexible regulation on the surface electronic properties. The defect type and their concentration within MXenes can significantly influence the overall performance of the final catalyst. It needs to be emphasized that the defects contribute to HER by effectively modulating surface functionalization rather than acting as a direct active site for catalysis. The doping of heteroatoms can effectively promote the electrocatalytic activity of MXenes. The introduction of heteroatoms as electron donors, O-terminations on the surface enables excessive electrons which could easily be transferred to the anti-bonding orbital of O-H, allowing the d-band center of the original transition metal to rise and weakening of the interaction between MXenes and H*, thus promoting the hydrogen desorption step in the HER process. Note that, in most cases, heteroatoms have only reported regulating the surface chemistry of MXenes instead of serving as new active sites for HER. Li et al. systematically studied HER performance of M2C (MXenes) doped with nonmetallic heteroatom X (X = N, B, P, S) through DFT theoretical calculation [61]. According to the ΔG H* values, nonmetallic atom doping can benefit in boosting HER performance, especially for N-Ti2C, which in theory, is an excellent HER catalyst. Lee et al. treated MXenes with ammonia to obtain nitrogen-doped MXenes [62]. The introduction of nitrogen successfully altered the electron configuration via forming a more favorable interaction of Ti-N in comparison to Ti-O bonds. This resulted in an overall improvement of conductivity and enhancement of intrinsic catalytic activity. Furthermore, the N-H and O-Ti-N components were also proven to contribute to improving catalytic activity alongside the Ti-N components. An et al. used triphenylphosphine (TPP) as a phosphorus source to generate P-doped V2CT x MXenes through heat treatment [63]. The theoretical calculations are shown in Fig. 7 (a) are indicative of the formed P-C bond and the adjacent O-terminations, which were proven effective active sites for HER. The phosphorus-doped MXenes obtained under 500 ℃ exhibited the best performance for HER in 0.5 M H2SO4, with an initial overpotential of −28 mV, η 10 of 163 mV, and a Tafel slope of 74 mV·dec−1. Transition metal atoms have also been considered as dopants. Applying first-principles calculations, Wang et al. found that the introduction of transition metal atoms, such as Fe, Co, and Ni, into V2CO2, could effectively weaken the interaction between O-terminations and H, resulting in lowering of ΔG H* value to 0 [64]. The substitution is another common strategy to improve the performance of the catalyst. Yan et al. used niobium (Nb) to substitute Ti atoms in Ti3C2T x -MXenes, providing extra electrons to raise the Fermi energy level to the conduction band, thus improving the charge transport properties [65]. At the same time, Ni/Co alloy was doped with MXenes using self-assembly and low-temperature reduction process, which adjusted the affinity between the surface “M” and H* to a moderate equilibrium position. Since Ni/Co are not active sites for electrocatalysis, the final product is still classified as pristine MXenes to highlight the catalytic role of MXenes in HER. The synthesized NiCo@Nb-doped Ti3C2T x (NiCo@NTM) with the optimal ratio exhibited a very low overpotential in 1.0 M KOH with a low η 10 of 43.4 mV (Fig. 7b). However, in terms of dynamics, the Tafel slope (Fig. 7c) reached 116 mV·dec−1, reflecting it as a prospective approach to further optimize the electrocatalysts. The possible reason for the high Tafel slope could be the less number of active sites that limit the kinetic process. As seen in Fig. 7(b), the Ni0.9Co0.1@NTM, which represents the best performance, clearly deviates from the baseline when the overpotential was 0, indicating that the capacitive current existed before the HER current could be measured [66]. Müller et al. reported Mo2CT x :Co, in which the cobalt has successfully substituted the molybdenum at the same coordination sites. The schematic and delaminated morphology is shown in Fig. 7(d and e) [67]. This approach was promising in overcoming the catalytic de-activation issue caused by server agglomeration of catalyst particles. 3 MXenes-based composite as HER electrocatalysts 3.1 MXenes-supported nanohybrids as HER catalysts The HER catalysts are usually nanoparticles owing to their high surface area and surface energy. Despite high catalytic activity, such particles are inclined to accumulate, leading to the catalytic de-activation. Thus, a suitable substrate is needed to ensure the stable dispersion of nanoparticles. In addition to the high specific surface area, MXenes have both robust electrical conductivity like graphene and excellent hydrophilicity like graphene oxide. Hence, MXenes can be expected to be a promising substrate in constructing nanohybrids based on their metal-like conductivity, rich surface chemistry, and high hydrophilicity, which provides it's the advantage of suitable interaction with various reactant components in the aqueous phase [68]. It has been found that Pt nanoparticles deposited on Ti3C2T x MXenes exhibit better HER activity with minimum Pt content [69–72]. In comparison, Wu et al. synthesized Pt single atom, Pt nanoparticles, and Pt3Ti loaded Ti3C2T x using in situ co-reduction at different temperatures [73]. The diffraction spots of Pt3Ti are shown in Fig. 8 (a). Here both experiments and calculations confirmed the formation of Pt3Ti. The Pt3Ti/Ti3C2T x composite (1.0 wt% loading of Pt) exhibited the best performance for HER in 0.5 M H2SO4, which was superior compared to Pt nanoparticles and Pt single atoms. In another approach, Yang et al. reported the growth of Pt/Ni ultrathin nanowires in situ on Ti3C2T x MXenes using surface oxygen-containing groups as the bridge [74]. Fig. 8(b and c) confirms the formation of Pt/Ni nanowires. The Pt3.21Ni@Ti3C2T x nanohybrid (2.09 wt% loading of PtNi) achieved superior HER activity in 0.5 M H2SO4 with a η 10 of 18.55 mV, and a Tafel slope with 13.3 mV·dec−1, following the Volmer-Tafel process. The developed catalyst exhibited good catalytic activity under alkaline conditions. Jaroniec et al. deposited NiS2 nanoparticles on V, and Ti-based MXenes using hydrothermal reaction and in situ chemical vapor deposition (CVD) respectively [75]. In their case, NiS2 with the V-based MXenes complexes (denoted as NiS2/V-MXenes) exhibited relatively superior catalytic performance compared to Ti-based. The NiS2/V-MXenes had a η 10 of 179 mV and a Tafel slope of 85 mV·dec−1. This difference in performance was directly related to the variance of contribution from the two MXenes in mass transfer and the electron transfer, as the strength of electron accumulation peak and consumption peak in the planar-averaged electron density difference, the diagram was higher for NiS2/V-MXenes than NiS2/Ti-MXenes (Fig. 8d). Meanwhile, the differential electron density map confirmed that the charge transfer in the case of NiS2/V-MXenes occurred throughout the hybrid, while in the case of NiS2/Ti-MXenes, it was limited only to surface (Fig. 8e). Liu et al. loaded black phosphorus (BP) quantum dots onto MXenes via self-assembly driven by Van der Waals forces [76]. Here, MXenes prevented BP quantum dots from aggregation to maintain their high electrocatalytic activity and ensured firm contact with the electrolyte. In turn, BP quantum dots prevent the nanosheet from disintegration. The synthesized BP QDs/MXene nanohybrid was tested for HER under the condition of 1.0 M KOH, where, Tafel slope of 83 mV·dec−1 with a η 10 of 190 mV was obtained. Qiu et al. processed MXenes into hierarchical 3D architecture by capillary-forced assembling strategy. Here MXene functioned as a substrate for metal oxide/phosphides. The composite architecture exhibited a favorable kinetic framework with high robustness, and excellent processability both in solution and solid-state. As a result, the CoP-3D MXene nanohybrids could also perform in alkaline electrolyte conditions [77]. Nanoparticles will reach a state of single-atom when the loading is sufficiently uniform and stable. This theory has been further developed in recent years [78–81]. In comparison to the traditional deposition approach, the purpose of single-atom catalysis is to maximize the catalytic activity of each atom to improve energy utilization efficiency. However, single atoms tend to aggregate in the external environment, resulting in lower utilization rate and lower activity. Therefore, it is still challenging to combine single atoms with 2D material in a stable manner while increasing the loading ratio of single atoms. In this regard, Wang et al. reported the formation of a large number of exposed Mo vacancies in the outer layers of the Mo2TiC2T x MXene nanosheet prepared by electrochemical exfoliation, as shown in Fig. 8(f and g) [82]. Incorporation of Pt single atom (PtSA) into the Mo vacancies significantly boosts the HER activity of MXenes (Fig. 8h), and the η 10 and η 100 were improved to 30 and 77 mV, respectively. Stability tests further demonstrated that PtSA remained stable for 100 h during HER without any de-activation or mass agglomeration. He et al. doped N and S atoms in Ti3C2T x , and then anchored Ru single atom (RuSA) over on MXenes through Ru-N bond and Ru-S bond. The obtained RuSA-N-S-Ti3C2T x nanohybrid showed good performance for HER with a η 10 value of 76 mV and a Tafel slope of 90 mV·dec−1 [83]. In contrary to MXenes doped with heteroatoms system, the single atom in this system directly act as an active site for HER. 3.2 MXenes-based heterostructure as HER catalysts Heterostructures are materials that have attracted extensive attention because of their multifunctional characteristics, which come from the synergic combination of its components. Inspired by the potential advantages, MXenes-based heterostructures have been designed and used in the area of microwave absorbing [84], batteries [85–88], photocatalytic [89], etc. They have recently sparked great interest in the field of HER. The strong interfacial interaction between MXene and the attached nanomaterials enables the MXene-based heterostructures to possess excellent structural stability and fast charge transfer kinetics. MoS2 is widely studied as a hydrogen evolution catalyst [90–93]. It belongs to a hexagonal crystal system with 1T phase and 2H phase. The 1T phase has good conductivity and catalytic activity; however, it tends to be unstable and transform to the 2H phase, which is stable but semiconductor in nature. By assembling 2H-MoS2 nanosheets on carbon-coated Ti3C2T x MXenes, Qiu et al. prepared MoS2/Ti3C2T x @C nanohybrid with excellent structural stability, electrical properties, and strong interfacial coupling [94]. The carbon layer coated on the MXenes played a vital role in preventing the degradation of MXenes structure, and the reducibility of the carbon material contributed to reducing the oxidation of external oxygen and oxygen-containing groups formed on the surface during the high-temperature annealing process (Fig. 9 a). The good electrical conductivity of MXenes and the good catalytic activity of 2H-MoS2 complemented each other, allowing the MoS2/Ti3C2T x @C to have a η 10 value of 135 mV and a Tafel slope of 45 mV·dec−1 in 0.5 M H2SO4. Fan et al. further explored the MoS2/MXenes system [95]. In this case, MoS2 was doped with Co to regulate the electronic structure effectively, thereby improving its inherent activity. Co-doped MoS2 then combined with Mo2CT x MXenes, which served as a conductive scaffold to promote electron transfer as well as providing active sites due to the HER activities of pristine MXenes. The nanocomposites exhibited satisfactory performance under alkaline conditions, with a η10 value of 112 mV and a Tafel slope of 82 mV·dec−1, while the Tafel slope of pristine Mo2CT x was 118 mV·dec−1. The decrease of the Tafel slope represented the transfer of the rate-limiting step from the adsorption process (Volmer reaction) to the desorption process (Tafel reaction or Heyrovsky reaction), demonstrating that Co-doped Mo2S endowed HER active sites. In a similar system, Tao et al. synthesized 1T/2H polyphase MoSe2 and compounded them with Ti3C2T x [96]. The polyphase system enabled the nanocomposite with decent electrical conductivity, abundant active sites, and good stability. In 1.0 M KOH solution, the as-prepared composites showed a η 10 value of 95 mV with a Tafel slope of 91 mV·dec−1. Besides the above-mentioned systems, Qiu et al. synthesized a more complex 3D electrocatalyst (Fig. 9b) with layered structure by assembling mesoporous NiFe-LDH nanosheet and 3D MXene foam through nickel foam (denoted as NiFe-LDH/MXene/NF) [97]. The main advantage of this catalyst was that it achieved an excellent catalytic effect under high current density. In 1.0 M KOH, the HER performance of NiFe-LDH/MXene/NF reached a much lower overpotential at the high current density of 500 mA·cm−2 as required by the market and with relatively superior durability at 10 mA·cm−2 than Pt/C/NF (Fig. 9c and d). 4 Conclusions and perspectives In summary, the birth of MXenes has injected new vigor into the selection of hydrogen evolution catalysts. This review intends to provide a guide for the future work related to the design of HER catalyst systems based on MXenes by in-depth profiling of the existing HER catalytic designs. The tunable compositions of “M” and “X”, flexible surface terminations, and devisable point defects have proven to be essential factors to drive HER activity of pristine MXenes to higher levels. Moreover, MXenes, with good electrical conductivity, rich surface chemistry, and hydrophilicity, can act as an ideal component for the construction of nanohybrid systems or heterostructures. In the case of MXenes-supported nanohybrids, MXenes remain a significant contributor to electron conduction and robust substrate to maintain the stability of the electrocatalytic system. The abundance of the MXene family has enabled researchers to apply them as optional substrate and optional loading material, where the presence of MXene plays a vital role in restricting the aggregation issues, limiting the de-activation of catalyst. It is therefore highly important that the interaction position and mode between the loadings and MXenes must be explored in greater detail during the experimental process to pinpoint the optimum substrate/loadings ratio. The synergistic effect of MXenes-based heterostructures has a significant influence on the structural stability and electrochemical activity of the system. Table 1 shows the HER performance of recently reported MXenes-based electrocatalysts. It is clear MXenes have promising application prospects and broad exploratory space in the field of HER. Future research must pave into exploring the electrocatalytic applications of new and novel MXenes members, such as double transition metal MXenes. Although the electron properties of the ordered double transition metal MXenes mainly depend on the outer layer transition metal, the presence of inner layer elements can reduce the formation energy of MXenes [98]. As an alternative, they can fill the bottleneck voids observed previously using single transition metal MXenes, thus broadening the choice range of electrocatalysts. In addition, the content of surface groups and the transverse size of the produced MXenes vary greatly with etching conditions. This makes it difficult to compare the catalytic activity of different MXenes by experimental means. The synthesis of MXenes with the proper surface electronic structure was observed to be the focus and challenge. Thus, exploring the proper synthesis methodology can further narrow the gap between theoretical prediction and presently reported experimental data. Besides, the defect engineering strategy of MXenes is also worth implementing. Besides doping and substitution strategies, the vacancy defects engineering is also a very effective method to enhance the activity of electrocatalyst, as such surface vacancies can influence the surface electronic properties of MXenes. MXenes-based composites are more attractive electrocatalysts for HER. In addition to Ti3C2T x , other configurations of MXenes should be introduced to diversify the search for the superior HER catalyst. The MXenes-based composites are also a possible route to overcome the oxidation issue of MXenes. Here, protective components such as carbon coating could realize a new pathway to achieve improvement in the oxidation stability of MXenes, leading to a prolonged life for the MXene-based catalytic system in a diverse range of applications. Finally, the de-activation mechanism of MXenes-based electrocatalyst could be excavated, considering the synergistic combination of experimental measurements and theoretical simulations. The changes in morphology, the composition of MXenes, the evolution of H2, transfer of active sites during the electrocatalytic process could be monitored and verified based on first-principles and in-situ characterization methods. Now she is pursuing a master's degree at Beijing University of Chemical Technology supervised by Prof. Bin Xu. Her research interests mainly focus on MXenes for electrocatalysis and batteries. Razium A. Soomro obtained his Ph.D. from the National Centre of Excellence in Analytical Chemistry (NCEAC) Sindh, Jamshoro in 2016. At present, he is working as a post doctorate researcher at Beijing University of Chemical Technology (BUCT). His area of expertise includes nanomaterials and 2D materials with application scope in sensors, energy, catalysis, and environment. Xiuqiang Xie received his Ph.D. degree in 2017 from University of Technology Sydney. He is now an associate professor at the College of Materials Science and Engineering at Hunan University. His main research interests include the synthesis of 2D materials and their heterostructures for sustainable technologies, such as photocatalysis, hybrid supercapacitors, and sodium-ion batteries. Bin Xu received his Ph.D. degree in 2006 from Beijing Institute of Technology. He worked at Drexel University as a visiting professor in 2016-2017. His current research interests focus on carbon materials and MXene-based materials for energy storage, including supercapacitors, secondary batteries such as lithium-/sodium-/potassium-ion batteries and lithium-sulfur batteries, electrocatalyst, and sensors. He has published more than 100 peer-reviewed papers in international journals with citations over 6000 times and H-index of 41.

coredata.dc:description: The growing energy concern all over the world has recognized hydrogen energy as the most promising renewable energy sources. Recently, electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) by water splitting has been extensively studied with a focus on developing efficient electrocatalysts that can afford HER at overpotential with minimum power consumption. The two-dimensional transition metal carbides and nitride, also known as MXenes, are becoming the rising star in developing efficient electrocatalysts for HER, owing to their integrated chemical and electronic properties, e.g., metallic conductivity, variety of redox-active transition metals, high hydrophilicity, and tunable surface functionalities. In this review, the recent progress about the fundamental understanding and materials engineering of MXenes-based electrocatalysts is summarized in concern with two aspects: i) the regulation of the intrinsic properties of MXenes, which include the composition, surface functionality, and defects; and ii) MXenes-based composites for HER process. In the end, we summarize the present challenges concerning the efficiency of MXenes-based HER electrocatalysts and propose the directions of future research efforts.
